Thanks for your email. I have had a look at the photos, and although it is sometimes hard to be sure with photos, I'd be very surprised if this was a fossil egg.  It does somewhat resemble an egg, but it is much more likely to be a sedimentary concretion of some kind ‚Äì it‚Äôs resemblance to an egg is merely accidental. Concretions often form when some object acts as a ‚Äúseed‚Äù for cementation of sediment. The subtle concentric layering adds weight to this interpretation. On occasion, the thing that initiates the concretion, the ‚Äúseed,‚Äù can be a fossil. To find this out would require finding out exactly what is in the center. 
Fossil eggs usually have an easily identifiable shell which differs significantly from the enclosed sediments either by having a fine, specific kind of surface ornamentation (the smoother the "shell," the less likely it is to be a non-bird dinosaur egg) or a specific type of crystalline structure in cross-section. Also, because eggshell is so brittle, the shell is almost always heavily cracked with apparent shifting of the eggshell bits ‚Äì the more perfectly ‚Äúegg-like‚Äù it is the less chance that it is a fossil egg. Ironically, one strong indication that this is not an egg is that it is so egg-shaped: most fossil eggs are not "egg-shaped" because most fossil eggs come from non-avian dinosaurs and are everything from spherical to torpedo-shaped. 
Additionally, the thickness of the ‚Äúshell‚Äù certainly rules out egg. Embryos in hard-shelled terrestrial eggs need shells through which they can conduct gas exchange ‚Äì basically so they can breathe. Past a certain thickness, this becomes impossible. This specimen‚Äôs ‚Äúshell‚Äù is much too thick.
As for the other piece, the photos are very blurry. If the pattern seen in the close-ups is what he thinks is fossil that pattern is actually merely the way rocks like that fracture.

I think Taenidium satanassi is a good start but I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs actually what it is. To find this out would require cracking the concretion open.
